instances.text: ARBC_V 205-001 - Beginning Classical and Quranic Arabic II

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Beginning Classical and Quranic Arabic II. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions.

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section in order of registration. If the course is blocked but showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

instances.text: ARCL_V 235-001 - Taming the Wild: Animals, Alcohol and Agriculture
ARTH_V 225-001 - Art, Patrons, and Audiences in the Middle Ages

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Who made art in the middle ages, who sponsored it, and who saw it? This course explores these questions by situating medieval art at the intersection of artistic creativity, concerns of patronage, and audience experiences. On the one hand, the course looks at a variety of mediums from manuscript paintings with limited audiences to public sculptures on monumental cathedrals, and on the other hand, it examines medieval art with culturally mixed audiences, and portable objects that crossed cultural, class-based, and gendered boundaries. As such, the course presents medieval art as a lived experience.

instances.text: ARTH_V 225-L01 - Art, Patrons, and Audiences in the Middle Ages
ARTH_V 225-L02 - Art, Patrons, and Audiences in the Middle Ages
ARTH_V 225-L03 - Art, Patrons, and Audiences in the Middle Ages
ARTH_V 253-001 - Asian Architecture: Sacred and Urban Spaces

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Through select case studies, this course examines city and representation in Asia. Our period focus is the uneven context of modernisation. Through lectures, group work, and individual research, students learn about the diversity of urban forms in Asia. They will learn to describe and compare different types of spatial practices, including architecture, lived space and spatial representation, and understand the different dynamics informing the development of the city and how it continuous to shape ideas about Asia.

instances.text: ASIA_V 200-021 - Cultural Foundations of East Asia

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as in-person are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to Waitlist and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
